text: There is no question that a lot of companies overhired during the pandemic. I go into some companies and honestly I can't believe all the ridiculous roles that they have, agile coaches and product owners and product ops and business analysts.
speaker: Marty Cagan
context: Lenny asks about the spiciness in Marty's recent writing, leading to a discussion about factors causing chaos in the product community. Marty explains that companies not only overhired during the pandemic but also lowered hiring standards, creating numerous unnecessary roles. He argues that many companies have created positions that don't add meaningful value compared to how the best product companies operate with leaner, more focused teams.
text_ko: 팬데믹 때 많은 회사가 채용을 과하게 한 건 분명해요. 몇몇 회사에 가 보면 솔직히 애자일 코치(agile coach), 프로덕트 오너(product owner), 프로덕트 운영(product ops), 비즈니스 애널리스트(business analyst) 같은 어처구니없는 직책들이 있는 걸 보고는 믿을 수가 없어요.
text_zh: 毫无疑问，疫情期间很多公司确实招人招得太猛了。我去一些公司看，说实话真是被他们那些莫名其妙的岗位给震惊了，什么敏捷教练(agile coach)啊、产品负责人(product owner)啊、产品运营(product ops)啊、业务分析师(business analyst)啊，一大堆。
text_es: No hay duda de que muchas empresas contrataron de más durante la pandemia. Entro a algunas empresas y la verdad no me puedo creer todos los puestos absurdos que tienen: coaches ágiles, product owners, product ops, analistas de negocio...

text: They're dramatically overpaid for the value they provide. Because it's a project management role. It is a lot easier to deliver output than it is to deliver outcomes.
speaker: Marty Cagan
context: Lenny describes Marty's concept of 'product management theater' - people who aren't real product managers but hold the title. Marty explains that many people calling themselves product managers are actually doing project management work, focusing on shipping features rather than solving problems. He emphasizes the critical difference between delivering output (shipping features) versus delivering outcomes (solving customer and business problems).
text_ko: 그들은 제공하는 가치에 비해 보수를 지나치게 많이 받고 있어요. 그건 프로젝트 관리 역할(project management role)이기 때문이에요. 산출물(output)을 내는 건 결과(outcome)를 만들어내는 것보다 훨씬 쉬워요.
text_zh: 他们拿的薪水跟他们创造的价值完全不成正比，拿得太多了。因为这就是个项目管理(project management)的活儿嘛。你要说交付成果(output)，那简单，但要真正实现效果(outcomes)，那就难多了。
text_es: Están súper sobrepagados para el valor que realmente aportan. Porque es un puesto de gestión de proyectos. Es mucho más fácil entregar productos que entregar resultados de verdad.

text: Too many people in our industry view themselves as a victim of their company, like they're stuck in a feature team and there's nothing they can do about it other than quit. I think that's not true. There is so much they can do.
speaker: Marty Cagan
context: Lenny asks what motivated Marty to write his third book, TRANSFORMED. Marty explains that many product professionals feel trapped in organizations that operate as 'feature teams' - teams given roadmaps of features to build rather than problems to solve. Instead of viewing themselves as powerless victims, Marty argues these individuals have much more agency than they realize to transform their companies and elevate their own roles.
text_ko: 우리 업계에서는 스스로를 회사의 피해자라고 보는 분들이 너무 많아요. 마치 기능팀(feature team)에 갇혀서 그걸 벗어날 방법은 그만두는 것뿐이라고 생각하죠. 저는 그게 사실이 아니라고 봐요. 할 수 있는 일이 정말 많아요.
text_zh: 我们这个行业里太多人都觉得自己是公司的受害者，好像被困在功能团队(feature team)里就没办法了，除了辞职别无选择。我觉得这想法不对，其实他们能做的事情多着呢。
text_es: Mucha gente en nuestra industria se ve como víctima de su empresa, como si estuviera atrapada en un equipo de desarrollo y no pudiera hacer nada más que renunciar. Yo creo que eso no es cierto. Hay muchísimo que pueden hacer.

text: We are looking for the commonality and mostly we're looking to help a company, whether it's a startup or a large company to have the best possible chance of success. That's the goal for us. It's a different goal.
speaker: Marty Cagan
context: Marty contrasts his approach with Lenny's podcast style. While Lenny seeks to showcase diverse perspectives and unique practices across different companies, Marty explains that his Silicon Valley Product Group focuses on identifying common principles and practices consistently used by the best product companies. Their heuristic requires seeing techniques used successfully by multiple proven companies before they evangelize them.
text_ko: 우리는 공통점을 찾고, 무엇보다 스타트업이든 대기업이든 회사가 성공할 가능성을 최대한 높일 수 있도록 돕는 데 집중하고 있어요. 그게 우리의 목표예요. 좀 다른 목표예요.
text_zh: 我们主要是在找共同点，更重要的是，我们想帮助公司——不管是初创公司(startup)还是大企业——让他们有最大的成功机会。这就是我们的目标，跟别人不太一样。
text_es: Buscamos los puntos en común y sobre todo queremos ayudar a una empresa, ya sea una startup o una compañía grande, a que tenga las mejores posibilidades de éxito. Ese es nuestro objetivo. Es un enfoque distinto.

text: I do. In fact, I've got some very uncomfortable things to talk about, which I know the more intelligent part of me is like, "Don't bring that up." But also the other side of me is like, "But people need to hear it."
speaker: Marty Cagan
context: Lenny asks about Marty's recent 'spiciness' in writing, suggesting he's telling people things they don't want to hear but need to hear. Marty confirms this is conscious - he's deliberately dialing up his rhetoric around uncomfortable truths in the product management industry. He acknowledges internal conflict between staying diplomatic versus sharing harsh realities that could help people and companies improve.
vocabulary_highlights: the more intelligent part of me
text_ko: 네, 있어요. 사실 꽤 불편한 얘기들이 있어요. 머리로는 '그 얘기 꺼내지 마'라고 하는데, 다른 한쪽은 '그래도 사람들이 들어야 해'라고 해요.
text_zh: 有啊。其实我有些挺敏感的话题想聊，我理智的那一面告诉我"别提这事儿"，但另一面又觉得"大家确实需要听听这些"。
text_es: Claro que sí. De hecho, tengo que hablar de algunas cosas bastante incómodas, y sé que la parte más inteligente de mí me dice "No saques ese tema." Pero por otro lado también pienso "La gente necesita escuchar esto."

text: And then the one that I really probably shouldn't bring up just because it's become a religious topic almost. I know it's a super sensitive topic for people, but the reality is with remote employees, both velocity and innovation have taken a real hit.
speaker: Marty Cagan
context: Marty discusses macro factors creating challenges in the product management field, including overhiring during the pandemic, rising cost of funds, and potential AI disruption. He addresses what he calls a 'religious topic' - the impact of remote work on product development. Despite knowing it's sensitive, he shares his observation that companies with remote teams struggle with both development speed and innovation compared to co-located teams.
text_ko: 솔직히 이 얘기는 거의 종교 논쟁 수준이라서 꺼내지 않는 게 나을 수도 있는데요. 사람들한테 정말 민감한 주제인 건 알고요. 그런데 현실은 원격 근무자의 경우 속도(velocity)와 혁신(innovation) 둘 다 실질적으로 큰 타격을 받았어요.
text_zh: 还有一个我本来不太想提的话题，因为这几乎成了一个很敏感的宗教话题了。我知道大家对这个都很敏感，但现实就是远程办公的员工，无论是工作效率还是创新能力，确实都受到了不小的冲击。
text_es: Y luego está el tema que probablemente no debería ni mencionar porque se ha vuelto casi como una religión. Sé que es un tema súper delicado para la gente, pero la realidad es que con los empleados remotos, tanto la velocidad como la innovación han sufrido un golpe bastante duro.
